item.gloss: Comely: 'attractive, beautiful, handsome; graceful, elegant', OEDO.
Nonage: ‘The state of being under full legal age; minority', OEDO.
Amain: ‘Immediately’, OEDO.

Witness: a godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term 'witness' interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Apprehension: ‘The action of “feeling” anything emotionally; sensitiveness’, OEDO.
Cordial: 'Heartfelt, hearty; sincere, genuine; thoroughly committed to a course of action or a cause', OEDO.
Trinity: 'The three “persons” or modes of being of the Godhead as conceived in orthodox Christian belief; the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as constituting one God', OEDO.

Measles: 'various … diseases causing a red rash', OEDO. See Alan Dyer, ‘Epidemics of Measles in a Seventeenth Century English Town’, Local Population Studies 34 (1985): 35–45.
Host or hosts of heaven: ‘The multitude of angels that attend upon God’, OEDO.
Incomprehensible: 'That cannot be contained or circumscribed within limits; illimitable, boundless, infinite; immense’, OEDO.
Understanding: 'Power or ability to understand’, OEDO.

Witness: a godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. Hypostatic union: Theologically, this term refers to the mystical union of both the divine and the human in the person of Jesus Christ. This concept is explained as “Christ is therefor both as God and as Man, that true vine whereof we both spiritually and corporally are branches…our very bodies through mystical conjunction receive from that vital efficacy' by Richard Hooker. See The Works of Mr. Richard Hooker … in Eight Books of Ecclesiastical Polity (London: Thomas Newcomb for Andrew Crook, 1666), 220-221.

Witness: a godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.
Stoop: 'A post, pillar', OEDO.

Causey: ‘raised way, either across low-lying land subject to flooding or at the side of tracks used by pedestrians and horses', Yorkshire Historical Dictionary, https://yorkshiredictionary.york.ac.uk/words/causey .

Standing: ‘Of a person, animal, etc.: that is in an upright position with the weight of the body supported by the feet’, OEDO. II.12.c. Used here to indicate that Thornton is trying to stop her horse from rearing: ‘to stand upon no ground: (of a horse) (probably) to rear up’, OEDO .

Anagram: ‘A rearranged or encoded version of something; a transposition', OEDO. The anagram only works if George’s surname is spelt Wandisford, as it is in the acrostic (below) but not at the top of the page (see image). This may suggest that neither were authored by Thornton: it is possible the author was Christopher Wyvill, who wrote his funeral eulogy, see Book 1, 114–15.
